questions.question: A company must decide whether to record an asset using historical cost (more verifiable) or fair value (more current). This decision primarily involves a trade-off between which qualitative characteristics?

options.A: Materiality and cost-benefit
options.B: Relevance and faithful representation
options.D: Timeliness and understandability

questions.explanation: Historical cost is more verifiable (faithful representation) while fair value may be more relevant for decision-making. The conceptual framework acknowledges that these fundamental characteristics sometimes involve trade-offs.
questions.tip: Relevance and faithful representation are the two fundamental qualitative characteristics that must both be present.

questions.question: A software company sells a software license bundled with two years of technical support. Under ASC 606, how should these be treated?

options.A: As a single performance obligation since they are sold together
options.B: As two separate performance obligations if the support is distinct
options.C: Revenue should be recognized entirely upon delivery of software
options.D: Revenue should be recognized entirely at the end of the support period

questions.explanation: Under ASC 606, goods or services are distinct if the customer can benefit from them independently. Software licenses and technical support are typically distinct because each can provide value independently.
questions.tip: Ask: Can the customer benefit from each item on its own? If yes, they are likely distinct performance obligations.

questions.question: A lessee enters into a 5-year equipment lease. The equipment has a useful life of 10 years and a fair value of $100,000. The present value of lease payments is $68,000. There is no transfer of ownership or purchase option. This lease should be classified as:

options.A: Finance lease because the lease term is more than 50% of the asset's useful life
options.B: Finance lease because the PV of payments exceeds 75% of fair value
options.C: Operating lease because no ownership transfer and PV is below 90%
options.D: Operating lease because no purchase option exists

questions.explanation: Lease term (5 years) is 50% of useful life (need >75% for finance). PV ($68,000) is 68% of fair value (need ≥90% for finance). No ownership transfer or purchase option. None of the finance lease criteria are met, so it's an operating lease.
questions.tip: Finance lease bright lines: >75% of useful life OR ≥90% of fair value. This lease meets neither.

questions.subtopic: Lower of Cost or Net Realizable Value
questions.question: Inventory has a cost of $50,000, a selling price of $55,000, disposal costs of $8,000, and a normal profit margin of $5,000. What is the inventory's net realizable value for LCNRV purposes?
questions.explanation: Net Realizable Value = Selling Price - Costs to Complete and Sell. NRV = $55,000 - $8,000 = $47,000. Normal profit margin is not subtracted under US GAAP LCNRV.
questions.tip: NRV = Selling price minus completion and disposal costs. Ignore profit margin for LCNRV.

questions.question: During construction of a building for its own use, a company should capitalize interest cost when:

options.A: Interest expense is material to the financial statements
options.B: Activities necessary to get the asset ready are in progress and expenditures have been made
options.C: The company has any debt outstanding during construction
options.D: The building is completed and ready for its intended use

questions.explanation: Interest capitalization requires: (1) expenditures for the asset have been made, (2) activities necessary to get the asset ready for use are in progress, and (3) interest cost is being incurred.
questions.tip: Three conditions must be met simultaneously for interest capitalization to begin.

questions.question: An investor owns 25% of an investee's voting stock and has significant influence. If the investee reports net income of $200,000 and pays dividends of $80,000, what is the impact on the investor's financial statements?

options.A: Investment income of $50,000; dividends reduce investment
options.B: Investment income of $200,000; dividends have no effect
options.C: Dividend income of $20,000; no other impact
options.D: Investment income of $50,000; dividends recognized as income

questions.explanation: Under the equity method: Investment income = 25% × $200,000 = $50,000 (increases investment). Dividends received = 25% × $80,000 = $20,000 (reduces investment, not income).
questions.tip: Equity method: Income increases investment, dividends decrease investment (not income).

questions.question: A company is involved in litigation where it is probable that it will lose and the loss can be reasonably estimated within a range of $100,000 to $300,000, with no amount more likely. How should this be recorded?

options.A: No accrual; disclose in notes only
options.B: Accrue $100,000 and disclose the range
options.C: Accrue $200,000 as the midpoint of the range
options.D: Accrue $300,000 as the maximum exposure

questions.explanation: When a loss is probable and estimable within a range with no amount more likely, the minimum of the range should be accrued. The full range should be disclosed in the notes.
questions.tip: Range with no best estimate = accrue the minimum. Always disclose the full exposure.

questions.question: A company has a deferred tax asset of $500,000 from net operating loss carryforwards. If management determines that it is more likely than not that only $350,000 of the DTA will be realized, what should be recorded?

options.A: DTA of $500,000 with no valuation allowance
options.B: DTA of $500,000 with valuation allowance of $150,000
options.C: DTA of $350,000 with no valuation allowance
options.D: No DTA should be recorded until realization is certain

questions.explanation: The full DTA ($500,000) is recorded, but a valuation allowance ($150,000) reduces it to the amount expected to be realized ($350,000). Net DTA on balance sheet = $350,000.
questions.tip: DTAs are recorded in full; valuation allowance reduces to expected realizable amount.

questions.question: A city operates a public swimming pool that charges admission fees intended to cover operating costs. This activity should be accounted for in which fund?

options.A: General fund
options.B: Special revenue fund
options.D: Internal service fund

questions.explanation: Enterprise funds are used for activities that charge fees to external users and are intended to be self-supporting. The swimming pool charges admission (user fees) to the public, making it an enterprise fund activity.
questions.tip: Enterprise = charges external users; Internal service = serves other government departments.

questions.question: A not-for-profit receives a donation of $100,000 with the stipulation that only the earnings can be spent on educational programs. How should this donation be classified?

options.A: Net assets without donor restrictions
options.B: Net assets with donor restrictions - purpose restricted
options.C: Net assets with donor restrictions - time restricted
options.D: Net assets with donor restrictions - perpetual in nature

questions.explanation: When a donor specifies that the principal must be maintained and only earnings can be used, this creates a perpetual restriction (endowment). The restriction on the corpus never expires.
questions.tip: Endowment = perpetual restriction. Earnings may have their own restrictions.

questions.question: In preparing the operating section of the statement of cash flows using the indirect method, a decrease in accounts payable should be:

options.A: Added to net income
options.B: Subtracted from net income
options.D: Ignored because it's a non-cash item

questions.explanation: A decrease in accounts payable means the company paid more cash to suppliers than the expenses recognized. This represents a cash outflow not reflected in net income, so it's subtracted.
questions.tip: Current liability decrease = cash outflow = subtract. Current asset decrease = cash inflow = add.

questions.question: Company A acquires 100% of Company B for $2,000,000 cash. Company B's identifiable assets have a fair value of $2,500,000 and its liabilities have a fair value of $800,000. What is the amount of goodwill recorded?

options.A: $0 (bargain purchase)

questions.explanation: Fair value of net identifiable assets = $2,500,000 - $800,000 = $1,700,000. Goodwill = Purchase price - Net identifiable assets = $2,000,000 - $1,700,000 = $300,000.
questions.tip: Goodwill = Purchase price minus fair value of net identifiable assets acquired.

questions.question: A US company records a sale to a British customer for 10,000 GBP when the exchange rate is $1.30/GBP. At collection, the rate is $1.35/GBP. What is the impact?

options.A: Foreign currency gain of $500
options.B: Foreign currency loss of $500
options.D: No impact; original sale amount is unchanged

questions.explanation: Receivable was recorded at 10,000 × $1.30 = $13,000. Collected at 10,000 × $1.35 = $13,500. The $500 difference is a foreign currency gain (GBP strengthened against USD).
questions.tip: When functional currency is USD: GBP strengthens = gain on GBP receivable; GBP weakens = loss.

questions.question: A company has net income of $500,000, 100,000 common shares outstanding all year, and cumulative preferred stock requiring annual dividends of $50,000. No dividends were declared this year. What is basic EPS?
questions.explanation: For cumulative preferred stock, the dividend is subtracted from net income regardless of whether declared. Basic EPS = ($500,000 - $50,000) / 100,000 = $4.50.
questions.tip: Cumulative preferred dividends are always subtracted for EPS. Non-cumulative only if declared.

questions.question: A company discovers that inventory at the end of Year 1 was overstated by $40,000. In Year 2, this error:

options.A: Should be corrected through current year cost of goods sold
options.B: Requires restatement of prior period financial statements
options.C: Has no effect because inventory errors self-correct
options.D: Should be reported as an unusual item in Year 2

questions.explanation: Errors are corrected by restating prior period financial statements (retrospective application). While inventory errors do self-correct over two years, the affected prior periods must still be restated.
questions.tip: Errors = restate. Changes in estimate = prospective. Changes in accounting principle = usually retrospective.

questions.question: Which of the following would be classified as a Level 2 input in the fair value hierarchy?

options.A: Quoted price for an identical asset in an active market
options.B: Quoted price for a similar asset in an active market
options.D: Management's estimate of future growth rates

questions.explanation: Level 2 inputs are observable inputs other than Level 1 quoted prices. This includes quoted prices for similar assets, interest rates, and yield curves. Level 1 = identical/active; Level 3 = unobservable.
questions.tip: Level 1 = identical/active. Level 2 = similar or inactive. Level 3 = unobservable/models.

questions.question: On January 15, Year 2 (before financial statement issuance), a company learns that a major customer filed for bankruptcy on December 20, Year 1. The company had significant receivables from this customer at December 31, Year 1. This is a:

options.A: Type I event requiring adjustment of Year 1 financial statements
options.B: Type II event requiring disclosure only
options.D: Subsequent event that affects Year 2 only

questions.explanation: Type I (recognized) events provide evidence about conditions that existed at the balance sheet date. The bankruptcy occurred before year-end, providing evidence that the receivable was impaired at December 31.
questions.tip: Type I = condition existed at balance sheet date (adjust). Type II = condition arose after (disclose).

questions.question: An operating segment must be reported separately if it meets which quantitative threshold?

options.A: Revenue is 5% or more of combined revenue of all segments
options.B: Profit/loss is 10% or more of the greater of combined profit or combined loss
options.C: Assets are 15% or more of combined assets
options.D: It employs more than 100 people

questions.explanation: A segment is reportable if: revenue ≥ 10% of combined revenue, OR profit/loss ≥ 10% of the greater of combined profits or combined losses, OR assets ≥ 10% of combined assets.
questions.tip: 10% rule for revenue, profit/loss, and assets. Employee count is not a criterion.

questions.question: Under cash flow hedge accounting, the effective portion of a derivative's gain or loss is initially reported in:

options.A: Net income immediately
options.B: Other comprehensive income
options.D: As an adjustment to the hedged item's carrying value

questions.explanation: Cash flow hedge gains and losses on the effective portion are recorded in OCI and reclassified to earnings when the hedged forecasted transaction affects earnings. Ineffective portions go to earnings immediately.
questions.tip: Cash flow hedge effective portion → OCI. Fair value hedge → Earnings immediately.

questions.question: A company grants 10,000 stock options on January 1, Year 1 with a 3-year service period. The grant-date fair value is $8 per option. What compensation expense should be recognized in Year 1?
questions.explanation: Total compensation cost = 10,000 × $8 = $80,000. This is recognized over the 3-year service period. Year 1 expense = $80,000 / 3 = $26,667.
questions.tip: Stock compensation = Grant-date fair value recognized straight-line over service period.

questions.question: A company incurs costs to develop a new software product for sale. Under US GAAP, which costs should be capitalized?

options.A: All development costs once a working model exists
options.B: Costs incurred after technological feasibility is established
options.D: Only costs incurred after commercial production begins

questions.explanation: For software developed for sale, costs incurred after technological feasibility is established are capitalized. Costs before technological feasibility are expensed as R&D.
questions.tip: Software for sale: Before tech feasibility = expense; After = capitalize. Software for internal use has different rules.

questions.question: Parent sells inventory to a 100%-owned subsidiary for $80,000 (cost $50,000). At year-end, 40% of this inventory remains unsold. What intercompany profit must be eliminated in consolidation?
questions.explanation: Total intercompany profit = $80,000 - $50,000 = $30,000. Only profit on unsold inventory must be eliminated. Elimination = $30,000 × 40% = $12,000.
questions.tip: Eliminate unrealized profit (inventory still on hand). Realized profit (sold to third parties) stays.

questions.question: A US company using LIFO for inventory is acquired by an IFRS reporting entity. How must the inventory accounting change?

options.A: LIFO may continue under IFRS as an allowed alternative
options.B: LIFO must be converted to FIFO or weighted average
options.D: No change is required as LIFO is permitted but not preferred

questions.explanation: LIFO is prohibited under IFRS. The acquired company must convert to an IFRS-permitted method such as FIFO, weighted average, or specific identification.
questions.tip: LIFO is allowed under US GAAP but prohibited under IFRS. Key convergence difference.

questions.question: Which of the following must be disclosed for related party transactions even if the terms are arm's length?

options.A: Only unusual transactions need disclosure
options.B: The nature of the relationship and description of transactions
options.D: No disclosure if transactions are at fair value

questions.explanation: Related party disclosures are required regardless of whether transactions are at arm's length. The nature of the relationship, transaction description, and amounts must be disclosed.
questions.tip: Related party disclosures are about potential conflicts of interest, not just fairness of terms.

questions.question: When evaluating whether there is substantial doubt about going concern, management should consider conditions and events for what time period?

options.A: Through the end of the next fiscal year
options.B: One year from the date the financial statements are issued
options.C: Six months from the balance sheet date
options.D: Indefinitely into the future

questions.explanation: Under US GAAP, management evaluates whether substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for one year from the date the financial statements are issued (or available to be issued).
questions.tip: The 1-year period starts from issuance date, not from balance sheet date.

questions.question: A company enters a contract with an $80,000 fixed fee plus a $20,000 performance bonus if certain targets are met. How should the revenue be recognized?

options.A: Recognize $100,000 immediately
options.B: Recognize $80,000 and constrain the bonus until highly probable it won't reverse
options.C: Recognize $80,000 only; bonus recognized when received
options.D: Recognize $90,000 using expected value approach

questions.explanation: Variable consideration (the bonus) should be estimated and included in the transaction price only to the extent it is highly probable that a significant reversal won't occur. The fixed fee is recognized per the contract terms.
questions.tip: Variable consideration = estimate then apply constraint (highly probable of no significant reversal).

questions.question: A company installs equipment with a legal obligation to remove it and restore the site at the end of its 10-year life. The estimated removal cost in 10 years is $500,000. How is the ARO initially recorded?

options.A: Liability of $500,000; no effect on asset
options.B: Liability at present value; equal amount added to asset cost
options.D: No recognition until costs are incurred

questions.explanation: An ARO is recorded at the present value of expected future cash flows. A corresponding amount is added to the carrying value of the related asset. The liability accretes over time; the asset addition is depreciated.
questions.tip: ARO: PV of future cost → liability and asset. Accretion expense + depreciation over time.

questions.question: Under the modified accrual basis used by governmental funds, property tax revenue should be recognized when:

options.A: The taxes are levied regardless of when collected
options.B: The taxes are measurable and available to finance current period expenditures
options.D: The fiscal year begins

questions.explanation: Under modified accrual, revenues are recognized when measurable and available. 'Available' typically means collectible within the current period or soon enough thereafter to pay current liabilities (usually 60 days).
questions.tip: Modified accrual = measurable and available. Full accrual = earned regardless of collection timing.

questions.question: A company reacquires 1,000 shares of its $5 par common stock for $25 per share using the cost method. Later, it reissues 600 shares for $30 per share. What is the credit to Additional Paid-in Capital from treasury stock transactions?
questions.explanation: Reissue: 600 shares × $30 = $18,000 received. Cost of reissued shares: 600 × $25 = $15,000. Excess over cost: $18,000 - $15,000 = $3,000 credited to APIC-Treasury Stock.
questions.tip: Cost method: Excess on reissue goes to APIC; deficiency first to APIC, then to Retained Earnings.

questions.question: A manufacturer leases equipment that it produces to a customer under terms that meet finance lease criteria. The manufacturer should account for this lease as:

options.A: Operating lease with rent revenue
options.B: Sales-type lease with profit recognition at commencement
options.C: Direct financing lease with interest income only
options.D: Failed sale with continued asset recognition

questions.explanation: When a lessor is a manufacturer or dealer and the lease transfers substantially all risks and rewards, it's a sales-type lease. Profit (difference between fair value and cost) is recognized at lease commencement.
questions.tip: Manufacturer/dealer + finance lease criteria = sales-type. Non-manufacturer = direct financing.

questions.question: Volunteers provide 500 hours of general office work to a not-for-profit organization. Should this be recognized as contribution revenue?

options.A: Yes, at estimated fair value of the services
options.B: Yes, at minimum wage times hours worked
options.C: No, because general services don't meet recognition criteria
options.D: No, because volunteers are never recognized

questions.explanation: Contributed services are recognized only if they: (1) create or enhance nonfinancial assets, or (2) require specialized skills, are provided by individuals with those skills, and would be purchased if not donated. General office work typically doesn't qualify.
questions.tip: Contributed services: Must be specialized skills OR create/enhance assets. General labor = no recognition.

questions.question: For a long-lived asset held for use, the impairment test sequence is:

options.A: Compare carrying value to fair value; write down if lower
options.B: Compare carrying value to undiscounted cash flows; if impaired, write down to fair value
options.C: Compare carrying value to discounted cash flows; write down if lower
options.D: Annually test at the lower of cost or market

questions.explanation: Step 1 (recoverability test): Compare carrying value to undiscounted future cash flows. If carrying value exceeds undiscounted cash flows, asset is impaired. Step 2: Measure impairment loss as carrying value minus fair value.
questions.tip: Two-step test: (1) Undiscounted CF for recoverability, (2) Fair value for measurement.

questions.question: Which of the following is required in an SEC registrant's annual Form 10-K filing?

options.A: Quarterly financial data for the past 3 years
options.B: Selected financial data for 5 years and MD&A
options.D: Monthly cash flow projections

questions.explanation: Form 10-K requires selected financial data for 5 years and Management's Discussion & Analysis (MD&A) covering liquidity, capital resources, and results of operations.
questions.tip: 10-K = annual. 10-Q = quarterly. MD&A is a key narrative requirement in both.

questions.conceptTested: Components of net periodic pension cost
questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of net periodic pension cost under US GAAP?

options.A: Service cost
options.B: Interest cost
options.D: Employer contributions to the plan

questions.explanation: Net periodic pension cost includes: service cost, interest cost, expected return on plan assets, amortization of prior service cost, and amortization of gains/losses. Contributions affect funded status but not pension expense.
questions.tip: Contributions reduce the liability but are not an expense component. Don't confuse funding with expense.

questions.question: Which of the following would be reported in other comprehensive income rather than net income?

options.A: Impairment loss on available-for-sale debt securities
options.B: Unrealized holding gain on available-for-sale debt securities
options.D: Gain on sale of equipment

questions.explanation: Unrealized holding gains/losses on AFS debt securities are reported in OCI until realized. Credit losses on AFS go to income. Foreign currency transaction gains go to income. Equipment sale gains go to income.
questions.tip: OCI items: AFS unrealized gains, foreign currency translation, pension adjustments, cash flow hedges.
